summary: Master the fundamentals of Canva for both web and mobile. This course covers everything from navigating the interface to creating your first designs.

lessons.title: What is Canva and Why Use It?
lessons.content:
Welcome to the World of Canva!

Canva is a powerful and user-friendly online design tool that allows anyone to create professional-looking graphics. You don't need to be a designer to use it! From social media posts to presentations, Canva simplifies the design process with its drag-and-drop interface and vast library of templates, fonts, and images.

Key Features:

  • Intuitive drag-and-drop editor.
  • Thousands of customizable templates for any occasion.
  • A rich library of photos, illustrations, icons, and fonts.
  • Collaboration features to work with a team.
  • One-click resizing for different platforms.
lessons.task: Explore the Canva homepage and identify three types of designs you'd like to create.

lessons.title: Navigating the Canva Dashboard
lessons.content:
Your Creative Command Center

When you log in, you'll see the Canva dashboard. It's designed to get you creating quickly.

Main Sections:

  • Top Bar: Search for templates or start a design with custom dimensions.
  • Side Panel: Access your projects, templates, brand kit, and other tools.
  • Main Area: See design suggestions, your recent projects, and different template categories like 'Presentations', 'Social Media', and 'Video'.

Spend a few minutes clicking around. The best way to learn is by exploring!
lessons.task: Find the 'Presentations' template category and open a template that catches your eye.

questions.question: What is the primary function of Canva?
questions.explanation: Canva's main purpose is to make graphic design accessible to everyone, regardless of skill level.

questions.question: Which feature is NOT a core part of Canva?
questions.explanation: While Canva is very versatile, it does not currently offer advanced 3D modeling capabilities.

lessons.title: Understanding the Editor Workspace
lessons.content:
The Anatomy of the Editor

The editor is where the magic happens. It's composed of a few key areas:

  • Side Panel (Objects Panel): On the left, you'll find everything you can add to your design: Templates, Elements (lines, shapes, graphics, photos), Uploads, Text, and more.
  • Top Toolbar (Contextual Menu): This bar changes depending on what element you have selected. If you select text, you'll see options for font, size, color, and spacing. If you select an image, you'll see options for editing the image, cropping, and effects.
  • The Canvas: This is your main design area where you will place and arrange all your elements.
lessons.task: Add a shape from the 'Elements' tab to your canvas and then select it to see how the top toolbar changes.

lessons.title: Working with Text and Fonts
lessons.content:
Making Your Message Stand Out

Text is a crucial part of most designs. Canva makes it easy to add and style text.

How to Add Text:

  1. Go to the 'Text' tab in the side panel.
  2. Click on 'Add a heading', 'Add a subheading', or 'Add a little bit of body text'.
  3. Alternatively, browse the font combinations for pre-designed text styles.

Once you have a text box, select it and use the top toolbar to change the font, size, color, alignment, spacing, and add effects like shadows or outlines.
lessons.task: Add a heading to your design. Change its font to 'Poppins' and set the color to a vibrant purple.

questions.question: Where would you find the option to add a photo to your design?
questions.explanation: The side panel contains all the objects and assets you can add to your canvas, including photos from Canva's library or your own uploads.

questions.question: The top toolbar in the Canva editor is 'contextual'. What does this mean?
options: It can be moved around the screen
It shows different options depending on the selected element
It contains context about your design
questions.correctAnswer: It shows different options depending on the selected element
questions.explanation: A contextual menu adapts its options based on the context, which in Canva's case is the specific element (text, image, shape) you have selected.
